sharpe_simon wrote:

> I hope to use JUNIT to teach programming to my Y1 students this year.
> I'd planned to write the test class, then ask the students to write
> the code e.g for a Book class, a test in the TestBook class might
> look like this.
> 
> public void testPrice()
> {
>       Book b1 = new Book();
>       b1.setPrice(7.99);
>       assertEquals(7.99, b1.getPrice(), 0.0799);
> }

Please, please, please do not use floating point numbers to represent 
quantities of money. This is a classic source of error in software, and 
I would hate to see you present it to students as a good idea.

Also, in your example, the price can be wrong by up to 1% in either 
direction! Is this really what you want? If the price comes back as 
7.93, that's good enough?! No way.

At least for now, use an integer to express price in cents, so you would 
have this:

public void testPrice()
{
       Book book = new Book();
       book.setPrice(799);
       assertEquals(799, book.getPrice());
}

There's also no reason to call the variable "b1". If it's a book, then 
call it a book.

> Sudents should write the set and get methods and set values
> correctly so this test is passed.
> 
> Problem : - I want them to work through the exercises and tests one
> at a time, but the test class will obviously not compile until all
> of the correct methods are in place in the Book class.

Why is this a problem? That's part of test-driven development: you write 
a test, then write enough code to make it /compile/, then run the test 
and watch it fail, then write enough code to make the test pass. That's 
"textbook" test-driven development, and exactly the way I teach it.

> Is my approach to this incorrect. Is there better way?

Well, your code needed some work, but your approach is solid.

> Hope you can help.

You be the judge. :)
